Shall sorrow dash gall on my strain,</br>While echo alarm'd in the dale,</br>Responds to compassionate pain</br>That flows for the partridge and quail;</br>Responds to the merciless gun,</br>If cruelty harbour a joy,</br>Then Doriland rise with the sun,</br>For privilege grants to destroy.

I sigh at the cruel decree,</br>My minstrelsy pity implores,</br>As well might the muse bid the sea</br>Forbear to contend with the shores:</br>'Tis done, and the covey must bleed,</br>The plume of the stubble must fall;</br>In silence I shrink at the deed,</br>For pity is deaf to my call.

Tho' nature seems prone to decay,</br>The coverts less russet appear;</br>Contracted the length of the day,</br>Announces the eve of the year:</br>September revolves with delight,</br>A coronet circles his head,</br>Emboss'd with fair blossoms of white</br>The hopes splendid incense has shed.

His mantle the vine leaves compose,</br>A holyhock purples his hand,</br>Th' arbutus, the larkspur and rose</br>Disdain not their charms to expand:</br>Bloom lupines and sweet-scented peas,</br>The tamarisk modest in hue;</br>The bean clad in scarlet to please,</br>And aconite's prodigal blue.

His reign shall the cricket attend,</br>The green-coated herald of cold,</br>Does winter this messenger send,</br>His embassy drear to unfold.</br>But why peevish insect thus pine?</br>Has Fate then ordain'd thee to weep?</br>While querulous notes, ever thine,</br>Deny the refreshment of sleep.

And thou on the wings of dull sound,</br>Who humm'st the drear knell of the day,</br>O say on what circumstance bound,</br>Agility hastens thy way:</br>Why thus giant beetle to roam,</br>In ebony panoply dress'd?</br>By war art thou urg'd from thy home?</br>Or art thou by enemies press'd?

When ev'ning's brown shadows extend</br>To my bow'r, still crested with green,</br>Without invitation my friend</br>Will Celadon honour the scene.</br>Of Phoebus to catch the last gleam,</br>While friendship our numbers shall fill,</br>Those numbers respond from the stream</br>That steals from the foot of the hill.

Or when with her crimson the morn</br>Dispels the black dreams of the night;</br>Her pencil the day to adorn,</br>Depaints lawny scenes to the sight:</br>When hinds are arouz'd to their toil,</br>And nymphs o'er the eminence gain,</br>Where Cantium with many a smile,</br>Of Ceres receives the rude train.

O then let us in early career,</br>Th' industrious vulgar survey,</br>To mirth and to jocus give ear,</br>For jocus and mirth lead the day:</br>The plant interdicted no more,</br>With floscles of silver behold,</br>While farmers, enrich'd by its store,</br>Sing "Silver's the mother of gold."

Why need that the muse should essay,</br>Or hint to the generous breast,</br>That he who is happy to day,</br>With pity should eye the distress'd;</br>Ye planters this precept to learn,</br>See providence please to bestow,</br>Solicits that grateful return,</br>To feel for the anguish of woe.

And shall the remonstrance of need</br>The abject and wretched unseen,</br>To plenty unaided proceed,</br>Return with disconsolate mien;</br>Forbid it ye virtues, whose tears</br>Ere start at the plaints of distress,</br>Whose sympathy misery rears,</br>Whose arms are extended to bless.

But where now, Aonian nine,</br>Are your measures aetherial pour'd,</br>In humaniz'd cadence divine,</br>For whom is your melody stor'd?</br>The bells, o'er the mist-crested ground,</br>Delightfully usher a peal,</br>That Hymen has sanction'd the sound,</br>My heart is the muse that must feel.

This day to her Celadon's breast</br>The peerless Penelope gives,</br>September be ever confess'd</br>What honour thy empire receives.</br>Bless'd pair!  for whom Hymen has wove</br>A wreath of unchangeable peace,</br>And supplicates blessings from Jove,</br>That time may affection increase.

Ye graces your beauties that lend,</br>Ye virtues that shed hallow'd fire,</br>Felicity beam on my friend,</br>The warmest, first lay of my lyre:</br>Fill, heaven, their measure of joys,</br>To bless their connubial solace,</br>Renown'd for his truth be their boys,</br>Their girls for her softness and grace.</br>
